codes.name: Research purpose
codes.description: states a purpose, problem, objective, or research question

codes.name: Motivation
codes.description: explains why the problem, objective, or research question is important (motivation)

codes.name: Definitions
codes.description: defines jargon, acronyms and key concepts

codes.name: Methodology
codes.description: methodology is appropriate (not necessarily optimal) for stated purpose or questions

codes.name: Data collection
codes.description: describes in detail what, where, when and how data were collected (see the Sampling Supplement)

codes.name: Data analysis description
codes.description: describes in detail how the data were analyzed

codes.name: Statistical assumptions
codes.description: discusses and validates assumptions of any statistical tests used

codes.name: Result presentation
codes.description: present results

codes.name: Result addressing research
codes.description: results directly address research questions

codes.name: Supported claims
codes.description: supports main claims or conclusions with explicit evidence (data/observations) or arguments

codes.name: Results implications
codes.description: discusses implications of the results

codes.name: Study limitations
codes.description: discusses the study's limitations and threats to validity

codes.name: Contribution to BoK
codes.description: contributes in some way to the collective body of knowledge

codes.name: Language misleading
codes.description: language is not misleading; any grammatical problems do not substantially hinder understanding

codes.name: Benefit risk balance
codes.description: balances the study's anticipated benefits with its potential risks or harms, minimizing risk or harm wherever possible (see the ethics supplements for studies with Human Participants or Secondary Data)

codes.name: Visualizations
codes.description: visualizations/graphs are not misleading (see the Information Visualization Supplement)

codes.name: Related work synthesis
codes.description: summarizes and synthesizes a reasonable selection of related work

codes.name: Relation with related work
codes.description: clearly describes relationship between contribution(s) and related work

codes.name: Epistemological stance
codes.description: states epistemological stance (e.g. post-positivism, interpretivism, critical realism)

codes.name: Statistical power/saturation
codes.description: appropriate statistical power (for quantitative work) or saturation (for qualitative work

codes.name: Limitations mitigation
codes.description: reasonable attempts to investigate or mitigate limitations

codes.name: Study realism
codes.description: discusses study’s realism, assumptions and sensitivity of the results to its realism/assumptions

codes.name: Recommendation providing
codes.description: provides plausibly useful interpretations or recommendations for practice, education or research

codes.name: Open sharing
codes.description: openly shares data and materials to the extent possible within practical and ethical limits (see the Open Science Supplement)

codes.name: Presentation
codes.description: concise, precise, well-organized and easy-to-read presentation

codes.name: Visualizations for argumentation
codes.description: visualizations (e.g. graphs, diagrams, tables) advance the paper’s arguments or contribution

codes.name: Researchers roles
codes.description: clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the researchers (i.e. who did what?)

codes.name: Auto-reflection
codes.description: provides an auto-reflection or assessment of the authors’ own work (e.g. lessons learned)

codes.name: Multiple raters use
codes.description: uses multiple raters for any subjective judgments (see the IRR/IRA Supplement)

codes.name: Multiple data collection
codes.description: applies two or more data collection or analysis strategies to the same research question (see the Multimethodology Standard)

codes.name: Multiple epistemological perspectives
codes.description: approaches the same research question(s) from multiple epistemological perspectives

codes.name: Research methodology innovation
codes.description: innovates on research methodology while completing an empirical study
describes the proposed artifact in adequate detail
justifies the need for, usefulness of, or relevance of the proposed artifact
conceptually evaluates the artifact; discusses its strengths, weaknesses and limitations

EITHER: discusses state-of-art alternatives (and their strengths, weaknesses and limitations) OR: explains why no state-of-art alternatives exist OR: provides compelling argument that direct comparisons are impractical

Empirically evaluates the proposed artifact using action research,in which the researchers intervene a real organization using the artifact, a case study in which a real organization uses the artifact without researcher intervention, a controlled experiment in which human participants use the artifact, a simulation in which the artifact is used in an artificial environment, or another method for which a clear and convincing rationale is provided
clearly indicates the empirical methodology being used (e.g. action research, controlled experiment)

EITHER: empirically compares the artifact to one or more state-of-the-art alternative artifacts OR: empirically compares the artifact to one or more state - of -the - art benchmarks OR: provides a clear and convincing rationale for why comparative evaluation is impractical
assumptions (if any) are explicit; do not contradict each other or the contribution's goals; plausibly hold for the evaluation subjects
uses notation consistently (if any notation is used)
